title: Why you procrastinate even when it feels bad

title: Are multivitamins really good for you?

options.text: To replace the nutrients obtained from a balanced diet.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between water-soluble and fat-soluble vitamins?

options.text: Water-soluble vitamins are stored in fatty tissues, while fat-soluble vitamins are easily excreted by the body.

options.label: B
options.text: Water-soluble vitamins are easily excreted by the body, while fat-soluble vitamins are stored in fatty tissues.

options.label: C
options.text: Both water-soluble and fat-soluble vitamins are stored in fatty tissues.

title: The best way to apologize (according to science)

multiple-choice.question: What is the centerpiece of an apology?

options.label: B
options.text: Asking the person how they were affected

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding and accepting responsibility for one's actions

options.label: A
options.text: To make the person apologizing feel better

options.label: B
options.text: To seek to understand the perspective of the wronged party and repair the damage to the relationship

options.label: C
options.text: To get forgiveness and move on

options.label: D
options.text: To express remorse and accept accountability

options.label: C
options.text: Blame someone else for their mistake

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore the situation and hope it goes away

options.label: C

options.text: A way to avoid taking responsibility for one's actions

options.text: Asking the person how they were affected

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To get forgiveness and move on

options.label: D
options.text: To express remorse and accept accountability

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: To ignore the situation and hope it goes away

title: Why it’s so hard to make healthy decisions - David Asch

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument of the speaker in the video?

options.label: A
options.text: That people behave rationally and make decisions based on information.

options.label: B
options.text: That conventional approaches to health education are effective.

options.label: C
options.text: That people are often irrational and that their decisions are influenced by emotions, framing, and social context.

options.label: D
options.text: That financial incentives are the most effective way to promote healthy behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how behavioral economics can be applied to improve health behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of electronic pill bottles with rewards and penalties.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of financial incentives to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of education to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of antibiotics to treat infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is present bias, and how can it lead to unhealthy behaviors?

options.label: A
options.text: Present bias is the tendency to prioritize short-term gains over long-term goals.

options.label: B
options.text: Present bias is the tendency to prioritize long-term goals over short-term gains.

options.label: C
options.text: Present bias is the tendency to make decisions based on information.

options.label: D
options.text: Present bias is the tendency to ignore social influence.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how social influence can shape health behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of electronic pill bottles with rewards and penalties.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of financial incentives to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of a photograph of eyes in a sink to increase handwashing rates.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of education to promote healthy behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: That people behave rationally and make decisions based on information.

options.label: B
options.text: That conventional approaches to health education are effective.

options.label: C
options.text: That working with the irrational parts of human nature can be more effective in improving health behavior and outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: That financial incentives are the most effective way to promote healthy behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how loss aversion can be used to promote healthy behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of financial incentives to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of education to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of a loss-framed incentive to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of antibiotics to treat infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of conventional approaches to health education?

options.label: A
options.text: They assume that people behave rationally and make decisions based on information.

options.label: B
options.text: They assume that people are always motivated to engage in healthy behaviors.

options.label: C
options.text: They assume that people are always aware of the risks and benefits of different behaviors.

options.label: D
options.text: They assume that people are always willing to pay for health care.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how behavioral economics can be applied to improve health behavior in a workplace setting?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of electronic pill bottles with rewards and penalties.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of financial incentives to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of a contest to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of education to promote healthy behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of using social influence to promote healthy behavior?

options.label: D
options.text: It can make people feel more comfortable engaging in healthy behaviors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the video in terms of the role of money in health care?

options.label: A
options.text: Money is the most effective way to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: Money can be a motivator, but it's far more influential when paired with psychology.

options.label: C
options.text: Money is not necessary to promote healthy behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: Money can only be used to promote unhealthy behaviors.

options.label: D

title: How do carbohydrates impact your health? - Richard J. Wood

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of carbohydrates in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide energy for the body

options.label: C
options.text: To support the growth and repair of tissues

multiple-choice.question: Which type of carbohydrate is composed of a single sugar molecule?
What is the glycemic index, and how is it affected by different types of carbohydrates?

options.label: A
options.text: The glycemic index is a measure of how quickly a food raises blood sugar levels, with high-glycemic foods releasing glucose quickly and low-glycemic foods releasing glucose slowly.

options.label: B
options.text: The glycemic index is a measure of how slowly a food raises blood sugar levels, with high-glycemic foods releasing glucose slowly and low-glycemic foods releasing glucose quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: The glycemic index is a measure of how a food affects insulin levels, with high-glycemic foods increasing insulin levels and low-glycemic foods decreasing insulin levels.

options.label: D
options.text: The glycemic index is a measure of how a food affects hunger levels, with high-glycemic foods increasing hunger and low-glycemic foods decreasing hunger.

multiple-choice.question: What is insulin sensitivity, and how is it affected by chronic carbohydrate consumption?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin sensitivity refers to the degree to which a unit of insulin lowers blood sugar, and chronic carbohydrate consumption can lead to increased insulin sensitivity.

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin sensitivity refers to the degree to which a unit of insulin lowers blood sugar, and chronic carbohydrate consumption can lead to decreased insulin sensitivity.

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin sensitivity refers to the degree to the degree to which a unit of insulin raises blood sugar, and chronic carbohydrate consumption can lead to increased insulin sensitivity.

options.label: D
options.text: Insulin sensitivity refers to the degree to which a unit of insulin raises blood sugar, and chronic carbohydrate consumption can lead to decreased insulin sensitivity.

multiple-choice.question: What is metabolic syndrome, and how is it related to insulin resistance?

options.label: A
options.text: Metabolic syndrome is a condition characterized by high blood sugar, increased waist circumference, and high blood pressure, and is not related to insulin resistance.

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic syndrome is a condition characterized by high blood sugar, increased waist circumference, and high blood pressure, and is a precursor to insulin resistance.

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic syndrome is a condition characterized by high blood sugar, increased waist circumference, and high blood pressure, and is a result of insulin resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolic syndrome is a condition characterized by high blood sugar, increased waist circumference, and high blood pressure, and is not related to insulin resistance.
